subs.text: üìö Catching up with John, the busted high-yield trader in Fooled by Randomness. If you are talking about a 10 sigma event you should have thought in alphas, not sigmas. There may be early hints that the data is not Gaussian but people call them outliers and brush them away. [link]
subs.rawText:
üìö Catching up with John, the busted high-yield trader in Fooled by Randomness.

If you are talking about a 10 sigma event you should have thought in alphas, not sigmas. There may be early hints that the data is not Gaussian but people call them outliers and brush them away. https://t.co/9dS3tchf95

subs.text: @GuruAnaerobic Ok, what is your (or someone else‚Äôs, I don‚Äôt care) best argument for why lockdowns in March 2020 weren‚Äôt justified ex ante? Because the only thing I‚Äôve seen so far is people using ex post (bad) or disputing the whole ex ante/ex post distinction (worse).
subs.rawText: @GuruAnaerobic Ok, what is your (or someone else‚Äôs, I don‚Äôt care) best argument for why lockdowns in March 2020 weren‚Äôt justified ex ante? Because the only thing I‚Äôve seen so far is people using ex post (bad) or disputing the whole ex ante/ex post distinction (worse).

subs.text: @TeaRespecter To clarify: are you saying that these comparisons (and let‚Äôs not go into how well they were made) can be used to assess wether or not the March 2020 lockdowns (not the later ones) were justified?

subs.text: üìö Fooled by hindsight bias. This one is for anyone who thinks lockdowns and school closures in the spring of 2020 were a mistake. Making ex post ‚Äúpredictions‚Äù is infinitely easier than ex ante, and gives you a false sense of confidence to boot. Dangerous and stupid. [link]
subs.rawText:
üìö Fooled by hindsight bias. This one is for anyone who thinks lockdowns and school closures in the spring of 2020 were a mistake.

Making ex post ‚Äúpredictions‚Äù is infinitely easier than ex ante, and gives you a false sense of confidence to boot. Dangerous and stupid. https://t.co/q5yHrHQ4zy

subs.text: The excerpt is from Fooled by Randomness by Nassim Taleb, paperback edition (2005).

subs.text: Several imprecisions in this essay on IRBs should not detract from its key point: social sciences don‚Äôt need IRB oversight, biomedicine needs it to be less byzantine and more transparent. Status quo is untenable. [link]

subs.text: July 1

Give a lecture once and you help a few hundred people (if you‚Äôre lucky). Post the lecture to YouTube and you help millions. 7 years later, I am yet to find a better guide to academic writing. NB: it‚Äôs good to have a live audience. [link]
